topics.topic_overview: Now we extend our inference methods to comparing two populations. This topic teaches you how to construct and interpret a confidence interval for the difference between two population proportions (p1 - p2). You will learn the four-step process for a two-sample z-interval for a difference between proportions. This includes checking the conditions for two independent random samples and calculating the interval using the appropriate formula. This procedure is widely used to estimate the size of the difference between two groups, such as the difference in the effectiveness of two treatments.

learning_objectives.summary: Identify an appropriate confidence interval procedure for a comparison of population proportions.
Verify the conditions for calculating confidence intervals for a difference between population proportions.
Calculate an appropriate confidence interval for a comparison of population proportions.
Calculate an interval estimate based on a confidence interval for a difference of proportions.

essential_knowledge.summary: The appropriate procedure for a two-sample comparison of proportions is a two-sample z-interval.
To calculate a confidence interval for a difference between proportions, check for independence and approximate normality.
The interval estimate for a comparison of proportions is (p1-hat - p2-hat) ± z* * SE.
Confidence intervals for a difference in proportions can be used to calculate interval estimates with specified units.

topics.topic_title: Justifying a Claim Based on a Confidence Interval for a Difference of Population Proportions
topics.ced_topic_title: Justifying a Claim Based on a Confidence Interval for a Difference of Population Proportions
topics.topic_overview: This topic focuses on interpreting the confidence interval for the difference between two proportions. The key is to look at whether the interval contains the value 0. If the interval is entirely positive or entirely negative, it suggests a real difference between the two population proportions. If the interval contains 0, then it is plausible that there is no difference between the proportions. You will practice writing clear, contextual interpretations of these intervals and using them to make decisions about claims comparing two groups.

learning_objectives.summary: Interpret a confidence interval for a difference of proportions.
Justify a claim based on a confidence interval for a difference of proportions.

essential_knowledge.summary: In repeated sampling, approximately C% of confidence intervals will capture the true difference in population proportions.
Interpreting a confidence interval for a difference in proportions should reference the samples and populations.
A confidence interval for a difference in proportions provides an interval of plausible values to support a claim.

topics.topic_title: Setting Up a Test for the Difference of Two Population Proportions
topics.ced_topic_title: Setting Up a Test for the Difference of Two Population Proportions
topics.topic_overview: This topic introduces the significance test for comparing two population proportions. You will learn how to write the null and alternative hypotheses for a two-sample z-test for a difference between proportions. The null hypothesis is typically that there is no difference (p1 - p2 = 0). You will also learn the conditions for this test, which are similar to those for the confidence interval but include a special way of calculating the standard error by 'pooling' or combining the two samples, based on the assumption that the null hypothesis is true.

learning_objectives.summary: Identify questions suggested by variation in the shapes of distributions of samples from the same population.

essential_knowledge.summary: Variation in the shapes of data distributions may be random or not.

topics.topic_title: Carrying Out a Test for the Difference of Two Population Proportions
topics.ced_topic_title: Carrying Out a Test for the Difference of Two Population Proportions
topics.topic_overview: This topic completes the four-step process for the two-sample z-test for a difference between proportions. You will learn how to calculate the pooled sample proportion, the test statistic, and the p-value. You will then practice making a conclusion by comparing the p-value to the significance level. The overall process is the same as for a one-sample test, but the formulas and conditions are specific to the two-sample case. Mastering this procedure will allow you to formally assess the evidence for a difference between two groups based on sample data.

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate an appropriate test statistic for the difference of two population proportions.
Interpret the p-value of a significance test for a difference of population proportions.
Justify a claim about the population based on the results of a significance test for a difference of population proportions.

essential_knowledge.summary: The test statistic for a difference in proportions is a z-statistic calculated using the combined (pooled) proportion.
Interpreting the p-value for a difference of proportions test assumes the null hypothesis (that the proportions are equal) is true.
A formal decision compares the p-value to alpha to reject or fail to reject the null hypothesis.
The results of a significance test for a difference of proportions provide statistical reasoning for a research question.

units.unit_title: Unit 7: Inference for Quantitative Data: Means

unit_overview.summary: In this unit, we extend the principles of statistical inference to quantitative data, focusing on population means. You'll learn the procedures for constructing confidence intervals and performing significance tests for a single population mean and for the difference between two population means. A key new element in this unit is the t-distribution, which we use when the population standard deviation is unknown. You'll learn how t-distributions differ from the Normal distribution and how to use them to perform inference. We'll also cover inference for matched pairs data, which is a special type of one-sample procedure. By the end of this unit, you'll have a complete set of tools for inference on the most common parameters: proportions and means.

topics.topic_title: Introducing Statistics: Should I Worry About Error?
topics.ced_topic_title: Introducing Statistics: Should I Worry About Error?
topics.topic_overview: This topic introduces inference for means by revisiting the core ideas of sampling variability and error. Just as sample proportions vary, sample means will also vary from sample to sample. Statistical inference provides a way to account for this random variation and make decisions in the face of uncertainty. We will explore how the principles of confidence intervals and significance tests that you learned for proportions can be adapted to work with quantitative data and population means. This topic sets the conceptual stage for the specific formulas and conditions you will learn in this unit.

learning_objectives.summary: Identify questions suggested by probabilities of errors in statistical inference.

essential_knowledge.summary: Random variation may result in errors in statistical inference.

topics.topic_title: Constructing a Confidence Interval for a Population Mean
topics.ced_topic_title: Constructing a Confidence Interval for a Population Mean
topics.topic_overview: How do we estimate an unknown population mean? This topic introduces the one-sample t-interval for a population mean. You will learn why we use a t-distribution instead of a Normal distribution when we have to estimate the population standard deviation from the sample data. We will cover the properties of the t-distribution, including its dependence on degrees of freedom. You will then learn the full four-step process for constructing and interpreting a confidence interval for a mean, including how to check the necessary conditions for inference on quantitative data.

learning_objectives.summary: Describe t-distributions.
Identify an appropriate confidence interval procedure for a population mean, including for matched pairs.
Verify the conditions for calculating confidence intervals for a population mean, including for matched pairs.
Determine the margin of error for a given sample size for a one-sample t-interval.
Calculate an appropriate confidence interval for a population mean, including for matched pairs.

essential_knowledge.summary: When s is used instead of sigma, the resulting t-distribution has more area in the tails than a normal distribution.
As degrees of freedom increase, the tails of a t-distribution get smaller, approaching a normal distribution.
When sigma is unknown, the appropriate procedure is a one-sample t-interval for a mean.
For a normally distributed variable, the statistic (x-bar - mu)/(s/sqrt(n)) follows a t-distribution with n-1 degrees of freedom.
Matched pairs data can be analyzed as a single sample of differences.
To estimate a population mean, check for independence and that the sampling distribution is approximately normal.
The critical value t* can be found using a table or technology.
The standard error for a sample mean is s/sqrt(n).
The margin of error for a one-sample t-interval is t* times the standard error.
The point estimate for a population mean is the sample mean, x-bar.
The confidence interval for a population mean is x-bar ± t*(s/sqrt(n)).

topics.topic_title: Justifying a Claim About a Population Mean Based on a Confidence Interval
topics.ced_topic_title: Justifying a Claim About a Population Mean Based on a Confidence Interval
topics.topic_overview: This topic focuses on the interpretation of the one-sample t-interval. As with proportions, you will practice interpreting the confidence interval and the confidence level in context. You will also learn how to use the interval to make a decision about a claim. If a hypothesized value for the population mean falls outside the confidence interval, we have evidence that the hypothesized value is incorrect. This provides a link between the two main methods of inference and gives you another tool for assessing claims.

learning_objectives.summary: Interpret a confidence interval for a population mean, including for matched pairs.
Justify a claim based on a confidence interval for a population mean, including for matched pairs.
Identify the relationships between sample size, confidence interval width, confidence level, and margin of error for a population mean.

essential_knowledge.summary: A confidence interval for a population mean either contains the mean or it does not.
We are C% confident that the interval captures the true population mean.
An interpretation of a confidence interval for a mean should reference the sample and the population.
A confidence interval for a population mean provides plausible values that can support a claim.
The width of a confidence interval for a mean tends to decrease as sample size increases.
The width of the interval for a single mean is proportional to 1/sqrt(n).
For a given sample, the width of the confidence interval for a mean increases as the confidence level increases.

topics.topic_title: Setting Up a Test for a Population Mean
topics.ced_topic_title: Setting Up a Test for a Population Mean
topics.topic_overview: This topic introduces the significance test for a population mean, the one-sample t-test. You will learn how to write the null and alternative hypotheses for a test about a population mean (μ). We will cover the conditions for this test, which are essentially the same as for the confidence interval: the data must come from a random sample, the 10% condition should be checked if sampling without replacement, and the population must be Normal or the sample size must be large (Central Limit Theorem). A key skill is checking the 'Normal/Large Sample' condition by examining the sample data.

learning_objectives.summary: Identify an appropriate testing method for a population mean with unknown sigma, including for matched pairs.
Identify the null and alternative hypotheses for a population mean with unknown sigma, including for matched pairs.
Verify the conditions for the test for a population mean, including for matched pairs.

essential_knowledge.summary: The appropriate test for a population mean with unknown sigma is a one-sample t-test.
Matched pairs data can be analyzed with a one-sample t-test on the differences.
The null hypothesis for a one-sample t-test is H0: mu = mu0.
When using matched pairs, it is important to define the order of subtraction for the mean difference.
To test a population mean, check for independence and that the sampling distribution is approximately normal.

topics.topic_title: Carrying Out a Test for a Population Mean
topics.ced_topic_title: Carrying Out a Test for a Population Mean
topics.topic_overview: This topic covers the 'Do' and 'Conclude' steps of the one-sample t-test. You will learn to calculate the t-test statistic and to find the p-value using the t-distribution with the appropriate degrees of freedom. You will then make a conclusion by comparing the p-value to the significance level. The overall logic is identical to the z-test for a proportion, but the mechanics involve the t-distribution. This topic also includes inference for the mean of differences from matched pairs data, which cleverly reduces a two-sample problem to a one-sample t-test.

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate an appropriate test statistic for a population mean, including for matched pairs.
Interpret the p-value of a significance test for a population mean, including for matched pairs.
Justify a claim about the population based on the results of a significance test for a population mean.

essential_knowledge.summary: The sampling distribution of the t-statistic for a mean has a t-distribution with n-1 degrees of freedom.
Interpreting the p-value for a test for a population mean assumes the null hypothesis is true.
A formal decision compares the p-value to alpha to reject or fail to reject the null hypothesis.
The results of a significance test for a mean provide statistical reasoning for a research question.

topics.topic_title: Confidence Intervals for the Difference of Two Means
topics.ced_topic_title: Confidence Intervals for the Difference of Two Means
topics.topic_overview: Now we turn to comparing the means of two independent groups. This topic introduces the two-sample t-interval for the difference between two population means (μ1 - μ2). You will learn the four-step process for this procedure, including the conditions for two independent random samples. The formula for the interval and the calculation of the degrees of freedom for the t-distribution are more complex here, and we will often rely on technology. The goal is to estimate the true difference between the means of the two populations.

learning_objectives.summary: Identify an appropriate confidence interval procedure for a difference of two population means.
Verify the conditions to calculate confidence intervals for the difference of two population means.
Determine the margin of error for the difference of two population means.
Calculate an appropriate confidence interval for a difference of two population means.

essential_knowledge.summary: The appropriate procedure for two independent samples is a two-sample t-interval for a difference between means.
To estimate a difference of means, check for independence of groups and that the sampling distribution is approximately normal.
The margin of error for the difference of two means is t* times the standard error of the difference.
The standard error for the difference in two sample means has a specific formula involving the sample standard deviations.
The point estimate for the difference of two population means is x1-bar - x2-bar.
The confidence interval for a difference of means is (x1-bar - x2-bar) ± t* * SE, with degrees of freedom found using technology.

topics.topic_title: Justifying a Claim About the Difference of Two Means Based on a Confidence Interval
topics.ced_topic_title: Justifying a Claim About the Difference of Two Means Based on a Confidence Interval
topics.topic_overview: This topic focuses on interpreting the two-sample t-interval. As with proportions, the key is to determine if the interval contains 0. If the interval is entirely positive or entirely negative, it provides evidence of a difference between the two population means. If the interval contains 0, then it is plausible that the means are the same. You will practice writing clear, contextual conclusions based on the interval. This method is a very common way to compare two groups in scientific research.

learning_objectives.summary: Interpret a confidence interval for a difference of population means.
Justify a claim based on a confidence interval for a difference of population means.
Identify the effects of sample size on the width of a confidence interval for the difference of two means.

essential_knowledge.summary: In repeated sampling, approximately C% of confidence intervals will capture the true difference of population means.
An interpretation for a confidence interval for the difference of two means should reference the samples and populations.
A confidence interval for a difference of means provides plausible values that can support a claim.
The width of the confidence interval for the difference of two means tends to decrease as sample sizes increase.

topics.topic_title: Setting Up a Test for the Difference of Two Population Means
topics.ced_topic_title: Setting Up a Test for the Difference of Two Population Means
topics.topic_overview: This topic introduces the two-sample t-test for the difference between two population means. You will learn to write the null and alternative hypotheses, where the null hypothesis is typically that there is no difference between the means (μ1 - μ2 = 0). We will review the conditions for this test, which are the same as for the two-sample t-interval. This procedure allows us to formally test a claim about the difference between two groups, such as whether a new drug is more effective than a placebo at reducing blood pressure.

learning_objectives.summary: Identify an appropriate selection of a testing method for a difference of two population means.
Identify the null and alternative hypotheses for a difference of two population means.
Verify the conditions for the significance test for the difference of two population means.

essential_knowledge.summary: The appropriate test for a difference of two population means is a two-sample t-test.
The null hypothesis for a two-sample t-test for a difference of means is H0: mu1 - mu2 = 0, or H0: mu1 = mu2.
To test a difference between means, check for independence and that the sampling distribution is approximately normal.

topics.topic_title: Carrying Out a Test for the Difference of Two Population Means
topics.ced_topic_title: Carrying Out a Test for the Difference of Two Population Means
topics.topic_overview: This topic completes the four-step process for the two-sample t-test. You will learn to calculate the test statistic and use technology to find the p-value from the appropriate t-distribution. You will then practice making a conclusion by comparing the p-value to the significance level. By the end of this topic, you will be proficient in carrying out a full significance test to compare the means of two independent groups, a very common and important statistical procedure.

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate an appropriate test statistic for a difference of two means.
Interpret the p-value of a significance test for a difference of population means.
Justify a claim about the population based on the results of a significance test for a difference of two population means in context.

essential_knowledge.summary: The sampling distribution of the t-statistic for a difference of two means is an approximate t-distribution, with degrees of freedom found by technology.
Interpreting the p-value for a test for a difference of means assumes the null hypothesis is true.
A formal decision compares the p-value to alpha to reject or fail to reject the null hypothesis.
The results of a significance test for a difference of means provide statistical reasoning for a research question.

topics.topic_title: Skills Focus: Selecting, Implementing, and Communicating Inference Procedures
topics.ced_topic_title: Skills Focus: Selecting, Implementing, and Communicating Inference Procedures
topics.topic_overview: This topic is a capstone for inference on means and proportions. You have now learned a variety of inference procedures. The goal here is to practice selecting the *correct* procedure for a given problem. You will learn to ask the key questions: Is this a problem about means or proportions? Is it one sample, two samples, or matched pairs? Are we estimating with a confidence interval or testing a claim with a significance test? This topic provides crucial practice in integrating your knowledge and making the right choices, which is a key skill for success in AP Statistics.

learning_objectives.summary: Identify questions suggested by probabilities of errors in statistical inference.

essential_knowledge.summary: Random variation may result in errors in statistical inference.

units.unit_title: Unit 8: Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square

unit_overview.summary: This unit expands your inference toolkit for categorical data. While previous units focused on proportions with only two categories (success/failure), the chi-square procedures you'll learn here allow you to analyze categorical variables with multiple categories. You will learn three different chi-square tests. The first is the chi-square test for goodness-of-fit, which tests whether the distribution of a single categorical variable matches a hypothesized distribution. The other two tests, the chi-square test for homogeneity and the chi-square test for independence, are used to analyze the relationship between two categorical variables. This unit will empower you to tackle a much wider range of questions involving categorical data.

topics.topic_title: Introducing Statistics: Are My Results Unexpected?
topics.ced_topic_title: Introducing Statistics: Are My Results Unexpected?
topics.topic_overview: This topic introduces the main idea behind the chi-square tests. We will explore situations where we want to compare observed counts from a sample to the counts we would expect to see if a certain theory or hypothesis were true. The core question is whether the differences between the observed and expected counts are large enough to be considered statistically significant, or if they could have happened just by chance. This sets the stage for the chi-square statistic, which is a measure of how far the observed counts are from the expected counts.

learning_objectives.summary: Identify questions suggested by variation between observed and expected counts in categorical data.

essential_knowledge.summary: Variation between observed and expected counts may be random or not.

topics.topic_title: Setting Up a Chi-Square Goodness of Fit Test
topics.ced_topic_title: Setting Up a Chi-Square Goodness of Fit Test
topics.topic_overview: This topic introduces the first of our three chi-square tests: the goodness-of-fit test. This test is used to determine if a hypothesized distribution for a single categorical variable is plausible. You will learn how to write the null and alternative hypotheses for this test. The null hypothesis states the specific proportions for each category, while the alternative is that at least one of the proportions is different. We will also cover the conditions for this test, which include random sampling and a new 'Large Counts' condition that requires all expected counts to be sufficiently large.

learning_objectives.summary: Describe chi-square distributions.
Identify the null and alternative hypotheses in a test for a distribution of proportions.
Identify an appropriate testing method for a distribution of proportions in categorical data.
Calculate expected counts for the chi-square test for goodness of fit.
Verify the conditions for making statistical inferences for a chi-square goodness-of-fit test.

essential_knowledge.summary: Expected counts are counts consistent with the null hypothesis, calculated as sample size times a probability.
The chi-square statistic measures the distance between observed and expected counts relative to expected counts.
Chi-square distributions are positive and skewed right; skew lessens as degrees of freedom increase.
For a goodness-of-fit test, H0 specifies proportions for each category, and Ha states at least one proportion is different.
For one categorical variable's distribution of proportions, the appropriate test is the chi-square test for goodness of fit.
Expected counts for a goodness-of-fit test are (sample size) * (null proportion).
For a chi-square goodness-of-fit test, check for independence and large counts (all expected counts >= 5).

topics.topic_title: Carrying Out a Chi-Square Test for Goodness of Fit
topics.ced_topic_title: Carrying Out a Chi-Square Test for Goodness of Fit
topics.topic_overview: This topic covers the 'Do' and 'Conclude' steps of the goodness-of-fit test. You will learn to calculate the expected counts for each category and then compute the chi-square test statistic. We'll explore the chi-square distribution, which is a new family of skewed distributions whose shape depends on the degrees of freedom. You will learn to use this distribution to find the p-value and then make a conclusion by comparing the p-value to a significance level. This procedure is useful for questions like, 'Does the distribution of colors of M&Ms match the company's claim?'

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate the appropriate statistic for the chi-square test for goodness of fit.
Determine the p-value for a chi-square test for goodness of fit.
Interpret the p-value for the chi-square test for goodness of fit.
Justify a claim about the population based on the results of a chi-square test for goodness of fit.

essential_knowledge.summary: The chi-square test statistic is the sum of (Observed - Expected)^2 / Expected, with df = number of categories - 1.
The null distribution for the chi-square statistic can be a randomization or theoretical chi-square distribution.
The p-value for a chi-square test is found using a table or technology.
The p-value is the probability of obtaining a test statistic as or more extreme than the observed value, assuming H0 is true.
The decision to reject or fail to reject H0 is based on comparing the p-value to alpha.
The results of a chi-square test for goodness of fit provide statistical reasoning for a research question.

topics.topic_title: Expected Counts in Two-Way Tables
topics.ced_topic_title: Expected Counts in Two-Way Tables
topics.topic_overview: Before we can perform chi-square tests on two-way tables, we need to know how to calculate the expected counts. This topic provides the necessary foundation. You will learn the formula for finding the expected count for any cell in a two-way table, which is based on the row and column totals. The logic is based on what we would expect to see if there were no association between the two variables. Mastering this calculation is a prerequisite for performing the next two types of chi-square tests.

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate expected counts for two-way tables of categorical data.

essential_knowledge.summary: The expected count in a cell of a two-way table is (row total * column total) / table total.

topics.topic_title: Setting Up a Chi-Square Test for Homogeneity or Independence
topics.ced_topic_title: Setting Up a Chi-Square Test for Homogeneity or Independence
topics.topic_overview: This topic introduces the two chi-square tests that use two-way tables: the test for homogeneity and the test for independence. Though the calculations are identical, their purpose and the way the data are collected are different. The test for homogeneity compares the distribution of a categorical variable across two or more different populations or treatment groups. The test for independence assesses whether there is an association between two categorical variables within a single population. You will learn how to write the hypotheses and check the conditions for both of these important tests.

learning_objectives.summary: Identify the null and alternative hypotheses for a chi-square test for homogeneity or independence.
Identify an appropriate testing method for comparing distributions in two-way tables of categorical data.
Verify the conditions for making statistical inferences for a chi-square test for independence or homogeneity.

essential_knowledge.summary: For a chi-square test for homogeneity, H0 states there is no difference in distributions across populations/treatments.
For a chi-square test for independence, H0 states there is no association between two categorical variables.
The chi-square test for homogeneity compares distributions of a categorical variable from different populations.
The chi-square test for independence assesses whether two categorical variables are associated in a population.
For chi-square tests on two-way tables, check for independence and large counts (all expected counts >= 5).

topics.topic_title: Carrying Out a Chi-Square Test for Homogeneity or Independence
topics.ced_topic_title: Carrying Out a Chi-Square Test for Homogeneity or Independence
topics.topic_overview: This topic completes the four-step process for the chi-square tests for homogeneity and independence. You will learn to calculate the chi-square statistic and the degrees of freedom for a two-way table. You will then use the chi-square distribution to find the p-value and make a conclusion. A significant result in a test for homogeneity means the distributions are different, while a significant result in a test for independence means there is an association between the variables. We'll also explore follow-up analysis to see which components contribute most to the chi-square statistic.

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate the appropriate statistic for a chi-square test for homogeneity or independence.
Determine the p-value for a chi-square test for independence or homogeneity.
Interpret the p-value for the chi-square test for homogeneity or independence.
Justify a claim about the population based on the results of a chi-square test for homogeneity or independence.

essential_knowledge.summary: The chi-square test statistic is the sum of (Observed - Expected)^2 / Expected, with df = (rows - 1)(cols - 1).
The p-value for a chi-square test for independence or homogeneity is found using a table or technology.
For a two-way table test, the p-value is the proportion of the chi-square distribution equal to or larger than the test statistic.
The p-value is the probability of obtaining a test statistic as or more extreme than the observed value, assuming H0 is true.
A decision to reject or fail to reject H0 is based on comparing the p-value to alpha.

topics.topic_title: Skills Focus: Selecting an Appropriate Inference Procedure for Categorical Data
topics.ced_topic_title: Skills Focus: Selecting an Appropriate Inference Procedure for Categorical Data
topics.topic_overview: This topic provides a crucial opportunity to synthesize your knowledge of inference for categorical data. You've learned about z-tests for one and two proportions, and now three different chi-square tests. The key skill here is to be able to read a problem and determine which of these five procedures is the correct one to use. We will practice distinguishing between these different scenarios. This skill of selecting the right tool for the job is one of the most important you will develop in this course.

units.unit_title: Unit 9: Inference for Quantitative Data: Slopes

unit_overview.summary: In our final unit, we return to the topic of linear regression and add the power of statistical inference. You've learned to describe the relationship between two quantitative variables and fit a regression line to sample data. Now, you will learn how to make inferences about the true relationship in the population. This unit focuses on inference for the slope of a population regression line. You will learn to construct a confidence interval for the true slope and to perform a significance test to determine if there is a genuine linear relationship between the variables. This unit completes your comprehensive introduction to the fundamental concepts and methods of AP Statistics, preparing you for the exam and for future studies in any data-driven field.

topics.topic_title: Introducing Statistics: Do Those Points Align?
topics.ced_topic_title: Introducing Statistics: Do Those Points Align?
topics.topic_overview: This topic introduces the concept of inference for regression. When we see a linear pattern in a scatterplot of sample data, how do we know if this reflects a true linear relationship in the population, or if it could have just happened by chance? You will learn to think of the observed slope of the sample regression line as just one possible slope from a sampling distribution of all possible slopes. This sets the stage for using confidence intervals and significance tests to make conclusions about the true population slope.

learning_objectives.summary: Identify questions suggested by variation in scatter plots.

essential_knowledge.summary: Variation in points' positions relative to a theoretical line may be random or non-random.

topics.topic_title: Confidence Intervals for the Slope of a Regression Model
topics.ced_topic_title: Confidence Intervals for the Slope of a Regression Model
topics.topic_overview: How can we estimate the true slope of the population regression line? This topic introduces the t-interval for the slope. You will learn the four-step process for constructing this interval. A key part of this is understanding the conditions for inference for regression, which include checking for a linear relationship, independent observations, Normal residuals, and equal variance of residuals. We will often use computer output to find the necessary values, so a key skill will be to read and interpret this output to find the sample slope and its standard error.

learning_objectives.summary: Identify an appropriate confidence interval procedure for a slope of a regression model.
Verify the conditions to calculate confidence intervals for the slope of a regression model.
Determine the given margin of error for the slope of a regression model.
Calculate an appropriate confidence interval for the slope of a regression model.

essential_knowledge.summary: The appropriate confidence interval for the slope of a regression model is a t-interval for the slope.

To calculate a confidence interval for slope, check that the relationship is linear, standard deviation of y does not vary with x, data are independent, and responses are approximately normal for each x.
The margin of error for the slope is t* times the standard error of the slope.
The standard error for the slope has a specific formula involving the standard deviation of residuals and the standard deviation of x values.
The point estimate for the slope of a regression model is the slope of the line of best fit, b.
The interval estimate for the slope is b ± t*(SE of b).

topics.topic_title: Justifying a Claim About the Slope of a Regression Model Based on a Confidence Interval
topics.ced_topic_title: Justifying a Claim About the Slope of a Regression Model Based on a Confidence Interval
topics.topic_overview: This topic focuses on interpreting the confidence interval for the slope. As with other parameters, you will practice writing a clear, contextual interpretation of the interval and the confidence level. A key use of this interval is to determine if there is a relationship between the variables. If the interval for the slope contains 0, it is plausible that the true slope is 0, meaning there is no linear relationship. If the interval does not contain 0, we have evidence of a genuine linear association.

learning_objectives.summary: Interpret a confidence interval for the slope of a regression model.
Justify a claim based on a confidence interval for the slope of a regression model.
Identify the effects of sample size on the width of a confidence interval for the slope.

essential_knowledge.summary: In repeated sampling, approximately C% of confidence intervals will capture the true population regression slope.
An interpretation of a confidence interval for slope should reference the sample and population.
A confidence interval for slope provides plausible values that can support a claim.
The width of the confidence interval for the slope tends to decrease as sample size increases.

topics.topic_title: Setting Up a Test for the Slope of a Regression Model
topics.ced_topic_title: Setting Up a Test for the Slope of a Regression Model
topics.topic_overview: This topic introduces the significance test for the slope of a regression line, known as the t-test for the slope. You will learn how to write the null and alternative hypotheses. The null hypothesis is almost always that the true population slope is 0, meaning there is no linear relationship between the variables. The alternative can be one-sided or two-sided. We will also review the conditions for this test, which are the same as for the confidence interval.

learning_objectives.summary: Identify the appropriate selection of a testing method for a slope of a regression model.
Identify appropriate null and alternative hypotheses for a slope of a regression model.
Verify the conditions for the significance test for the slope of a regression model.

essential_knowledge.summary: The appropriate test for the slope of a regression model is a t-test for a slope.
The null hypothesis for a t-test for a slope is H0: beta = beta0, with one- or two-sided alternatives.
To test a regression slope, check that the relationship is linear, standard deviation of y is constant, data are independent, and responses are normal for each x.

topics.topic_title: Carrying Out a Test for the Slope of a Regression Model
topics.ced_topic_title: Carrying Out a Test for the Slope of a Regression Model
topics.topic_overview: This topic completes the four-step process for the t-test for the slope. You will learn to find the t-test statistic and the p-value from computer output. You will then make a conclusion by comparing the p-value to the significance level. A small p-value provides evidence against the null hypothesis and suggests that there is a genuine linear relationship between the variables in the population. This test is the formal way to confirm that a pattern we see in a scatterplot is statistically significant.

learning_objectives.summary: Calculate an appropriate test statistic for the slope of a regression model.
Interpret the p-value of a significance test for the slope of a regression model.
Justify a claim about the population based on the results of a significance test for the slope of a regression model.

essential_knowledge.summary: The null distribution for the slope of a regression model is a t-distribution.
The sampling distribution of t = (b - beta) / SEb has a t-distribution with df = n-2.
Interpreting the p-value for a test for slope assumes the null hypothesis is true.
A formal decision compares the p-value to alpha to reject or fail to reject the null hypothesis.
The results of a significance test for slope provide statistical reasoning for a research question.

topics.topic_title: Skills Focus: Selecting an Appropriate Inference Procedure
topics.ced_topic_title: Skills Focus: Selecting an Appropriate Inference Procedure
topics.topic_overview: Congratulations, you have reached the end of the new material for AP Statistics! This final topic is a comprehensive review of all the inference procedures you have learned throughout the course. You will practice distinguishing between problems involving proportions, means, and slopes, and between one-sample, two-sample, matched pairs, and chi-square scenarios. Mastering the ability to select, implement, and communicate the results of the correct inference procedure is the ultimate goal of this course and will prepare you well for the AP exam.
